resources.string: An Intent is a messaging object you can use to request an action from another app component, such as starting an activity. It\'s a way for different parts of your app (or even different apps) to communicate and work together.
An explicit intent is a type of intent in Android that directly specifies the target component (Activity, Service, or Broadcast Receiver) that should be invoked.
In Android, we often need to pass data between activities. This is where explicit intents come in handy
Activity with Data: Passing Data Between Activities
Activities and Objects in Android: A Deep Dive
In Android, an Activity is a single, focused thing that the user can do. It represents a single screen with a user interface. When you launch an app, you\'re typically launching an Activity.

In Android, startActivityForResult() is a method used to start an Activity and receive a result back. This is useful for scenarios where you want to initiate an action in a separate Activity and then get a result back to the original Activity.
